channel.title: Apple Basics ðŸ“š on Analyst
channel.description: Recent content in Apple Basics ðŸ“š on Analyst

item.title: Apple Encryption
item.description: Applications or even OS itself doesn’t know the keys that are protected by Secure Enclave. OS only sees Keychain, but the Security Enclave is separated.

item.title: Apple Hiberbation
item.description: Hibernation files store the last state of RAM before “falling asleep” ðŸ’¤ . These files are of a particular value when live acquisition is impossible.

item.title: Apple Logs
item.description: Since macOS Sierra (10.12, 2016) Apple has redesigned its log system. Unix logs were replaced (syslog, for example).

item.title: Apple Mach-O File
item.description: Intro Using otool we can get general info about the Mach-O file: otool -h [app_name] > Mach header magic cputype cpusubtype caps filetype ncmds sizeofcmds flags 0xfeedfacf 16777228 0 0x00 2 115 11384 0x00218085 Quick refernce on the meaning:

item.title: FSEvents
item.description: Intro Directory events only 10.5-10.6. File events since 10.7. Each record is assigned a name which is constucted the following way: hex(last_event_id + 1).

item.title: MacOS Basics
item.description: Firewall You can set specific rules to limit the traffic. FireVault No recovery once this password is lost.

item.title: Apple LAContext vs User Presence
item.description: In this article I’n going to research this: how LAContext is different from User Presence, in what way it’s better.

item.title: Mac Artifacts
item.description: User Data /Users/%username%/ Password hashes sudo plutil -p /var/db/dslocal/nodes/Default/users/<usename>.plist Account Info sudo plutil -p /private/var/db/dslocal/nodes/Default/Users/<User>.plist Contains name, profile name, password hint, account image, UID

item.title: RAM Collection on macOS
item.description: On the forensicswiki [1] there is the list of tools to be used for RAM acquisition. I’ve tried several of them and realised, that the current problem of the forensic community is that the tools get old much faster than the information gets updated… Sadly.

item.title: Apple File Systems
item.description: HFS HFS+ Supports large files Efficient disk space usage unicode for filenames name forks file compression journaling dynamic resizing, defragmentation not only for MacOS APFS Clones Snapshots Space sharing encryption crash protection sparse files fast directory resizing iOS has two partitions: system and user.
